data.title: Fantino
data.meta_description: Fantino is a town in the Sánchez Ramírez Province of the Dominican Republic. The population was 22,487 at the 2012 census. data.text:
Fantino is a town in the Sánchez Ramírez Province of the Dominican Republic. The population was 22,487 at the 2012 census. Part of the town is within the boundaries of Aniana Vargas National Park.

Overview[]

The Fantino municipality is located in the eastern part of the of DR's Cibao Valley, and is the westernmost of the 4 municipalities that make up the Sánchez Ramírez province.

History[]

Although its beginnings date back to the end of the 18th century under the name of La Piña, this community began to develop in the middle of the next century by people who emigrated from nearby towns.

After the creation of the Sánchez Ramírez province in 1952, it received the category of municipal district, and then it was elevated to a municipality in 1962.

Geography[]

Fantino is located at 19.1195° N, 70.2974° W. According to the ONE, the town has a total land area of 95.97 square kilometers (37.05 square miles). It is bordered by the Duarte Province city of San Francisco de Macorís and town of Las Guáranas on the northeast, the town of La Mata on the east, the city of Cotuí on the south, and the La Vega Province town of Jima Abajo on the west and city of Concepción de la Vega on the northwest. It is located in the northwestern part of the province. Fantino has a municipal district; Fantino (town center).

Economy[]

Bathed by its rivers and streams, Fantino is one of the largest rice producers in the Dominican Republic. It also has plantations of cocoa, corn, pineapple and other fruits.

Its economy also benefits from mining with the exploitation of gold, silver and copper.

Heritage[]

Its patron saint festivities are celebrated every year on June 6 in honor of the Sacred Heart of Jesus, and various activities are carried out such as artistic presentations and horse and bicycle races.

This is a region rich in socio-cultural activities. In recent years, clubs and associations have proliferated. These include the Lions Club, the Association of University Students, the Association of Teachers, the Association of Physicians, the Association of Private Employees, the Association of Drivers, the Association of Parceleros, the Club 4 de Julio and the Association of Housewives.
